attributes.title: How does the implicit processing of facial expression modulate saccade programming?
attributes.description: The aim of this project is to study the implicit influence of emotion on the programmation of saccades toward faces.

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: How does the implicit processing of facial expression modulate saccade programming?

other.value:
Data collection is currently underway but we have not looked at the data so far. Apart from the main question, the following analyses will be carried out :

(1) Analysis of EFE effects on saccade endpoints: The vertical distance between saccade endpoints and the image center will also be studied as a dependant variable, depending on the EFE. We expect that saccades will land lower on the image when the face is happy, then fearful, then neutral, due to the weights of salient local features on the saccade map (Entzmann et al., submitted).

(2) Analysis of Target effects on saccade latency and accuracy: Studies have shown that female faces are more easily associated with expressions of happiness and fear, and that male faces are mostly associated with angry faces (Hess et al., 2009). In this sense we can think that when participants are asked to go toward a female face (compared to a male face), they would be even more efficient when the face is emotional (happy or fearful) because of this association. We can therefore assume that the emotional face advantage would be stronger when the target is a female face. A repeated measures ANOVA with the Target (Male, Female) and the EFE (Happy, Fearful, Neutral) will be used to test for this interaction.

(3) Analysis of within-group effects on saccade latency and accuracy: We can also expect that participants will be better at detecting an individual from their own group (e.g., a woman will be better at detecting a woman's face; Cellerino et al., 2004). To test for this effect we will use a mixed-design ANOVA with the Gender of participants (Male or Female) as a between subject factor and the Target (Male or Female) as a within subject factor to test for this interaction.

Fianlly, we will probably also have a look at second saccade characteristics and hemifield effects.

sample.value: We plan to recruit between 45 and 60 healthy, right-handed participants, between 18 and 30 years old. Indeed, we expect to analyse the results of at least 40 participants. The effect size of our previous study using a similar procedure with an explicit instruction allows us to calculate a sample size (using G*Power software with a power of .80 at the standard .05 alpha error probability; estimate sample size was 17). Because in the present experiment, we use an implicit processing of emotion and we did not find any study that allows a precise estimate (i.e., a study with facial expressions, saccadic responses, and an implicit instruction) we choose to consider a larger sample size.

analyses.value: A repeated measures ANOVA will be used with the EFE (Happy, Neutral and Fearful) and the Target (Male, Female) as within subject factors. To examine our main question (i.e., see if emotional faces are preferentially processed in an implicit task), the study of the main effect of the EFE is sufficient. Still, the Target*EFE interaction is considered because it is important for secondary analyses (see next section). Also, paired sample t-tests will be used for pairwise comparisons. For all analyses, in case statistical assumptions are not fulfilled, a non parametric Friedman test or a Wilcoxon signed rank test will be used to replace the ANOVA and the t-tests respectively.

outliers.value: Some trials will be excluded from all analysis. First all the trials for which the first saccade is not valid; a saccade is valid if it is the first event after the stimulus onset, if no blink occurs during the stimulus display, if the first saccade has a latency higher than 50 ms (latency shorter corresponds to anticipatory saccade), if the saccade start in an area of 2° around the center of the screen, if its duration is shorter than 100 ms and finally if the saccade amplitude is higher than 1° and inside the screen. We classically used these criteria and remove around 15 % of trials.

dependent.value: The main dependent variables are the Latency and the Accuracy of the first saccade. The latency represents the time between the image onset and the beginning of the first saccade. The accuracy represents the proportion of correct saccades, i.e., the proportion of saccades directed toward the target (and thus, not toward the other image).

conditions.value: The main independent variable is the Emotional Facial Expression of the target, which could be either a fearful, happy or neutral face. An other important independent variable is the Target, which could be the male or the female face, depending on the session. The design is within subject, i.e., participants are tested on each EFE and Target condition.

hypothesis.value:
Theoretical context: The aim of the experiment is to quantify the impact of face emotion on visual attention through a paradigm, called saccadic choice task, which uses saccades as responses. During this paradigm based on eye-tracking, two images, from different visual categories, are simultaneously displayed on a screen and participants are asked to make a saccade as fast as possible toward the image corresponding to a target category, for example a face and the other image is an animal or a vehicle (Crouzet et al., 2010; Kirchner and Thorpe, 2006; Guyader et al, 2017; Kauffmann et al. 2019). These studies investigated the extremely fast toward faces. 
Others studies had also used this paradigm with two images of faces, one with an emotion and the other without emotion. Performances were found to be better (fewer errors and shorter latency) when participants were asked to saccade toward the emotional rather than the neutral face. Moreover, performances were even better when the emotional face was happy rather than fearful  (Entzmann et al., submitted; Bannermann et al., 2009; Calvo et al., 2011). These results were obtained when participants were explicitly asked to process the facial expressions as it was necessary to perform the task. Nevertheless, there are evidences suggesting that the emotional content of visual stimuli can captures visual attention even when the attention is focused on a non-emotional aspect of these stimuli (i.e., reflecting the implicit processing of the emotional content; Habel et al., 2007; Bayle et al., 2009; Williams et al., 2009; D’Hondt et al., 2016). But to our knowledge none of this evidence were based on facial expressions and saccadic measures. And it is still unclear whether the preferential processing of emotional faces, and more specifically happy faces in saccadic choice tasks can be extended to tasks that doesn’t require an explicit processing of emotion.

Goal: The goal of the current experiment if to test whether the preferential processing of emotional faces, and more specifically happy faces in saccadic choice tasks, is preserved when participants are not explicitly asked to process facial expressions. To this aim, the paradigm is based on a  saccadic choice task with a neutral and an emotional face presented simultaneously (one male, one female); participants are asked to direct their gaze toward the male or the female face (the task does not imply the process of the emotion).

Hypothesis: Mainly, we expect that even in a task in which participants are not asked to process facial expressions, emotional faces are preferentially processed over neutral faces (higher accuracy, shorter latency). This would be in agreement with studies using either a manual response with faces (Bayle et al., 2011), or a saccadic response with emotional scenes (D’Hondt et al., 2016). Concerning differences between happy and fearful faces, two alternative hypotheses can be assumed based on different models of emotion processing. First, from a perceptual point of view, happy faces are easier to recognize and to detect in a crowd of neutral face by both humans and artificial neural networks (Calvo et al., 2011, 2009; Mermillod et al., 2009). In this sense, if perceptual saliency is more important to capture visual attention happy faces could be more likely to attract the gaze compared to fearful faces (Calvo et al., 2011, 2009). On the other hand, fearful faces are known to be related to a faster activation in the amygdala, which have been explained by their higher relevance for survival (Ledoux, 2000). In this sense they could be preferentially processed over the happy faces due to their higher relevance.

attributes.title: Effect of early initiation of renal replacement therapy in patients with acute respiratory distress syndrome: a systematic review and meta-analysis.
attributes.description: Effect of early initiation of renal replacement therapy in patients with sepsis-associated acute kidney injury: a systematic review and meta-analysis

q1.value: Effect of convalescent blood products for patients with severe acute respiratory infectious of viral etiology: A systematic review, meta-analysis and meta-regression.

q2.value: Tong Zhaohui, Shao, Shuai, Kang, Hanyujie

q3.value: In December 2019, a series of pneumonia cases with unknown causes appeared in Wuhan, Hubei Province, China, with fever, dry cough, and fatigue as the main clinical manifestations. The novel coronavirus was identified by deep sequencing of lower respiratory tract samples. The International Committee on virus classification named the new virus SARS-CoV-2. The World Health Organization named the disease caused by the virus as Coronavirus Disease 2019. In the latest novel coronavirus pneumonia diagnosis and treatment plan (trial version 7) from China, "convalescent plasma therapy" is classified as one of the treatment methods for heavier and critical patients, and has aroused wide attention from all of the world. Because we know little about the Coronavirus Disease 2019, we could only conclude the application of convalescent blood products in other severe acute respiratory infections of viral etiology, hoping to provide a theoretical basis for the treatment of patients with Coronavirus Disease 2019.

q4.value: Compared to placebo or traditional care, could convalescent blood products decrease the mortality of patients with severe acute respiratory infectious of viral etiology?

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: A systematic search of clinical trials published between January 1, 1918, and February 22, 2020, was conducted using PubMed, Embase, Cochrane Library, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials and Web of Science. The search terms we used were “Middle East Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus”, “SARS virus”, “Influenza, human”, “immunization, passive”, "plasma", "serum", "immunoglobulins", "blood transfusion", "convalescent"and “immune". We applied no restrictions on the type of trial and language. Eligible articles were identified for inclusion by screening the titles, abstracts, and full text. Other relevant studies were manually screened by investigators from the reference list of included studies for further analysis.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

question.value: The interventional and control groups had to have included hospitalized patients with a diagnosis of severe acute respiratory infections of viral etiology, and investigators had to report mortality rates or the timing of initiation of convalescent blood product therapy. We will not exclude the children, pregrant women. Duplicates, studies did not focused on severe acute respiratory infections of viral etiolog patients, studies did not provide the outcomes which we need and those articles which did not clearly compare the convalescent blood with the standar care (or placebo) will be excluded. We will e-maile the corresponding authors of the eligible articles for further details, if available. Any uncertainty will be resolved by discussion with the third researcher. Studies had to have used convalescent blood products like whole blood, plasma, serum or hyperimmune immunoglobulin obtained from humans who had recovered from severe acute respiratory infections of viral etiology as the treatment product and had to indicate the type, route and treatment strategy of convalescent blood products which were applied among patients. In the control groups, patients should be gave placebo or standard treatment without convalescent blood products. We will include randomized controlled trials(RCTs), cohort studies as well as case series to assess the beneficial effects of the convalescent blood products.

q13.value: The literature systematically searched yielded 17456 references in four electronic databases that were subsequently refined to 17 eligible studies for further consideration which included three RCTs, one prospective cohort study, three retrospective case comparison studies and 6  case series.

question.value: The primary outcome is Mortality(28-day mortality, all-cause mortality). The secondary outcomes are adverse events and the effect of earlier initiation of convalescent blood products among patients with severe acute respiratory infections of viral etiology.

The risk of bias in eligible RCTs or prospective cohort studies will be examined by the Cochrane Collaboration risk of bias tool.Trials will be rated as"low," "unclear," or "high" in several domains. Two investigators will evaluate the bias from random sequence generation, allocation concealment, blinding of participants and personnel, blinding of outcome assessment, incomplete outcome data, selective reporting and other bias. The Newcastle-Ottawa Scale (NOS) will be selected to judge the quality of retrospective cohort studies which concentrates on three aspects: selection, comparability, and outcome (range 0−9 stars). Disagreements between the review authors over the risk of bias in any study will be resolved by discussion, with involvement of a third review author where necessary. We will generate summary estimates of mean and standard deviation (SD) for continuous outcomes. Values for dichotomous results are given as the odds ratios (OR) with 95% CI. A random-effects model will be used due to the significant heterogeneity identified between studies, otherwise, the fixed effects model will be performed. We will pool data of dichotomous by Mantel-Haenszel (M-H) statistical models. Results will be adjusted by adding 0.5 to each cell of the contingency table when no deaths occurred in the interventional group in individual trials. The estimation of effect will be summarized by the forest plot. The value of P < 0.05 is considered statistically significant for all research. I² testing will be applied to assess the heterogeneity between trials (where a value of >50% is regarded as indicating substantial heterogeneity). Sensitivity analyses will be conducted by sequentially omitting one study each time to identify the potential influence. We will judge the publication bias for the outcomes which contained more than five trials by creating a funnel plot and applying traditional statistical methods (Egger's test). Grading of Recommendations Assessment, Development, and Evaluation (GRADE) approach will be applied to judge the quality of evidence for the primary and secondary outcomes. Meta-regression using a random-effects model analysis will be performed to reveal the potential covariates of studies if there is any statistically significant or methodological heterogeneity. The investigators will construct meta-regression by using the following aspects as covariates: publication year, race, article sample size, the proportion of male (%), mean age, Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (SOFA) score, Acute Physiology, and Chronic Health Evaluation (APACHE) II score. The statistical analyses will be completed using Review Manager Version 5.3, Stata version 15.1 and GRADE Profiler version 3.6.
For subgroup analysis, the following variables will be selected before the study is undertaken: study method (RCT or cohort study); different viral aetiology(SARS virus, Infuenza A virus, Ebola virus, or MERS Virus); type of convalescent blood products( plasma, serum, hyperimmune immunoglobulin or whole blood); timing of initiation of convalescent blood products (earlier versus later). A test of interaction will be performed on all subgroups to determine whether the difference between subgroups is statistically signiﬁcant.

attributes.title: Efficacy and Safety of Chinese Herbal Medicine for COVID- 19: a protocol for systematic review and meta-analysis
attributes.description: Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is a global pandemic caused by the Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus-2 (SARS-CoV-2). The patients of COVID-19 usually present with fever, cough, while about 23.7% of patients are accompanied by at least one coexisting disease. The disease is highly contagious with a R0 value about 3-4. The rapid increase in the number of patients put great pressure on the health care system. With the aggravation of the shortage of medical treatment, the mortality rate of the disease increases. As of 15:00 on March 31, 2020, 793278 people were diagnosed with the disease and at least 38545 died. At present, there is no specific cure for this disease, and the clinical management mainly depends on supportive treatment. Lopinavir-Ritonavir was once thought to be a promising medicine on COVID-19, but a recently published clinical trial found that the effect was limited. As excessive immune response is an important reason for the progression of the patient's condition, the researchers turned their attention to immunosuppressants. In a small sample clinical trial, the researchers found that Hydroxychloroquine could improve the state of patients' lungs and increase the probability of the virus turning negative. However, the sample size of this study is small, and there may be some defects in the research design. In a case report, Remdesivir has shown good efficacy in patients with COVID-19, and larger clinical trials are currently under way. Therefore, it is an important and urgent task to explore new therapeutic agents. In the fourth edition of the diagnosis and treatment guideline of COVID-19 in China, Lianhuaqingwen capsule was listed as one of the recommended medicines. In addition, traditional Chinese medicines (CHM), including Qingfei Paidu decoction, Huanglian Jiedu decoction etc., are also widely used in the adjuvant treatment of COVID-19. In terms of clinical research, many scholars have carried out clinical trials on the efficacy of CHM in treating COVID-19. However, these studies are only carried out in local areas, so they fail to provide definite evidence to prove the effectiveness of CHM. In this study, we aim to summarize the current evidence of CHM in treating COVID-19 through systematic review and meta-analysis. This study is necessary before further large-scale clinical studies being carried out. For clinicians, this study can provide some direction and guidance for clinical practice.

q2.value: This study aims to investigate the effects of Chinese herbal medicine in treating COVID-19.

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Randomized controlled trials (RCTs) can provide evidence about efficacy of intervention, so they will be included in this systematic review. However, the outbreak of COVID-19 is an urgent public health event, and it is difficult to carry out RCTs, so non-randomized controlled trials will also be included in this study, although non-randomized controlled trials (non-RCTs) may be more biased than RCTs.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Three English database including PubMed, Embase, Cochrane Library Central Register of Controlled Trials and four Chinese databases including China National Knowledge Infrastructure (CNKI) database, Wanfang Data Knowledge Service Platform, the VIP information resource integration service platform (cqvip), China Biology Medicine Disc (Sino Med) will be searched from its inception to April 1, 2020 without language limitation. Preprinted website including arXiv (http://arxiv.org/), BioRxiv (https://www.biorxiv.org/), F1000 (https://f1000.com/) and PeerJ Preprints (https://peerj.com/preprints/) will also be searched to find out more unpublished papers. In addition, Chinese Clinical Trial Registry (ChiCTR) and ClinicalTrials.gov will also be searched to find out ongoing research. 
A search strategy of the combination of controlled vocabulary and text words will be adopted. Boolean operators will be used to concatenate search terms. This work will be conducted by two authors ( Zhipeng Hu and Maoyi Yang) independently.
EndNote X9 will be used by two researchers (Zhipeng Hu and Maoyi Yang) to screen the citations independently according to the predefined inclusion and exclusion criteria. Discrepancies between two authors will be solved by discussion with a third author (Rensong Yue).

q11.value: There will be no limitation about sample size.

question.value: Since there are no core outcome sets for COVID-19, it is difficult to predefined what outcomes will be included in our study. In general, any outcome that can reflect the condition will be included in this study.

Data analysis will be conducted using Stata 14.0 software. The effect measure of binary variable will be expressed as risk ratio (RR) or odds ratio (OR) and 95% confidence interval (CI). For continuous variables, 95% CI and mean difference (MD) or standardized mean difference (SMD) will be used. The number needed to treat (NNT) will be calculated for the interpretation of results. Cochrane X2 and I2 tests will be conducted to assess the heterogeneity analysis between studies. When P < .05 and I2>50%, a random effect model will be used. When P > .05 and I2<50%, then a fixed effect model will be used to calculate the effect size. The results of RCTs and non-RCTs will be analyzed and presented independently. Subgroup analysis will be conducted to explore the subgroup effects and investigate the source of heterogeneity. If there is a substantial heterogeneity and quantitative synthesis is not appropriate, the results will be presented in the form of tables and figures. 
Publication bias and small-study effects will be evaluated by funnel plot and statistically investigated by Egger’s test with a P value boundary of .05.

Preprinted website including arXiv (http://arxiv.org/), BioRxiv (https://www.biorxiv.org/), F1000 (https://f1000.com/) and PeerJ Preprints (https://peerj.com/preprints/) will also be searched to find out more unpublished papers. In addition, Chinese Clinical Trial Registry (ChiCTR) and ClinicalTrials.gov will also be searched to find out ongoing research. 
A search strategy of the combination of controlled vocabulary and text words will be adopted. Boolean operators will be used to concatenate search terms. This work will be conducted by two authors ( Zhipeng Hu and Maoyi Yang) independently.
EndNote X9 will be used by two researchers (Zhipeng Hu and Maoyi Yang) to screen the citations independently according to the predefined inclusion and exclusion criteria. Discrepancies between two authors will be solved by discussion with a third author (Rensong Yue).

attributes.title: Latent Correlations Between Trait Aggression and Trait Antagonism
attributes.description:
In this follow-up study, I will again test the prediction that the antagonism (low agreeableness) factor of the Five Factor Model (FFM) of personality will account for the overwhelming majority of the variance in trait aggression (latent correlations > .60). Other FFM factors will exhibit latent correlations < |.60|. 

Exploratory analyses with the IPIP-NEO-120 FFM and Brief Aggression Questionnaire supported these predictions. Subsequent confirmatory analyses with the Big Five Inventory and full Buss-Perry Aggression Questionnaire only weakly supported these predictions. This may be due to the different content in the Agreeableness subscales of the NEO and BFI.

I will now seek to confirm the exploratory analyses by replicating them in a dataset from an existing laboratory study with 424 undergraduate participants who completed the 12-item Brief Aggression Questionnaire measure of trait aggression and the 60-item NEO-Five Factor Inventory scale.

I will use the lavaan package for R to run factor analyses for each FFM facet using the following design:

LatentCorr.mod <- 'BAQtotal =~ BAQphysical + BAQverbal + BAQanger + BAQhostility
IPIPagreeableness =~ NEO.4 + NEO.9 + NEO.14 + NEO.19 + NEO.24 + NEO.29 + NEO.34 + NEO.39 + NEO.44 + NEO.49 + NEO.54 + NEO.59
IPIPconscientious =~ NEO.5 + NEO.10 + NEO.15 + NEO.20 + NEO.25 + NEO.30 + NEO.35 + NEO.40 + NEO.45 + NEO.50 + NEO.55 + NEO.60
IPIPextraversion =~ NEO.2 + NEO.7 + NEO.12 + NEO.17 + NEO.22 + NEO.27 + NEO.32 + NEO.37 + NEO.42 + NEO.47 + NEO.52 + NEO.59
IPIPneuroticism =~ NEO.1 + NEO.6 + NEO.11 + NEO.16 + NEO.21 + NEO.26 + NEO.31 + NEO.36 + NEO.41 + NEO.46 + NEO.51 + NEO.56
IPIPopenness =~ NEO.3 + NEO.8 + NEO.13 + NEO.18 + NEO.23 + NEO.28 + NEO.33 + NEO.38 + NEO.43 + NEO.48 + NEO.53 + NEO.58'

fitmod <- cfa(LatentCorr.mod, data=[Dataset], missing='ML')

summary(fitmod, fit.measures=TRUE, standardized = TRUE)

I will then report the standardized latent correlations for each FFM factor. I will interpret that my hypotheses are supported if the latent correlation between trait aggression and agreeableness is more negative than -.60, and if the latent correlations between trait aggression and the four other FFM factors are < |.60|.

summary.value: This preregistration is for a second replication of an exploratory analysis, in which the latent correlations between trait aggression and each of the factors of the Five Factor Model.

attributes.title: The Relationship Among Chronic Stress, Anxiety, and Attentional Control
attributes.description:
Attentional Control Theory (ACT), which has received consistent support (Shi et al., 2019), proposes that the ability to successfully shift and focus attention is interrupted by anxiety, as attention is allocated to perceived threatening information (Eysenck et al., 2007). Emerging adulthood tends to be a time of increased anxiety symptoms (Barsy et al., 2010; Daviu et al., 2019; Edwards et al., 2017; Hidalgo et al., 2001; Kumsta et al., 2017; McLaughlin & Hatzenbuehler, 2009; Miloyan et al., 2018), and AC is especially important at this time in order to excel in undergraduate programs. Thus, it is important to study potential mechanisms that contribute to the anxiety – attentional control (AC) link during this period. 
Stress, which is also highly prevalent in young adults, specifically college undergraduates, is a well-known risk factor for anxiety (Sarafino & Ewing, 1999) and has also been correlated with impaired AC (Bardeen & Daniel, 2017; Gulley et al., 2016; Jonsdottir et al., 2017; Kushner & Tackett, 2017; Laceulle et al., 2015; Liston et al., 2006, 2009; Orem et al., 2008; Shields et al., 2016; Skosnik et al., 2000). The well-established relation between stress and anxiety may help explain the negative relation between stress and AC. Therefore, since stress is a known risk factor for both anxiety and impaired AC, and anxiety is known to impair AC, anxiety may mediate the relation between stress and AC. The current study assessed whether anxiety mediates the effect of stressful life events on AC over time.

q1.value: The Relationship Among Chronic Stress, Anxiety, and Attentional Control

q3.value: Since stress is a known risk factor for both anxiety and impaired AC, and anxiety is associated with impaired AC, there is evidence to posit a mediation effect of anxiety on the link between stress and AC.

q4.value: First, we hypothesize more SLEs at T1 will predict higher levels of anxiety at T2.  Secondly, we hypothesize higher levels of anxiety at T2 will predict decreases in AC at T3.  Thirdly, we hypothesize SLEs at T1 will predict decreased AC at T3.  Lastly, we hypothesize anxiety at T2 will mediate the relation between SLEs at T1 and AC at T3.  For the alternative model, we will test whether SLEs at T2 mediate the relation between AC at T1 and anxiety at T3. All models will be run controlling for variables at baseline to predict change over time.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The current study was part of the larger, longitudinal study, College Cognition and Coping (C3).  Participants in the current study were comprised of 224 students ages 18-23 (M=19.30, SD =1.27).

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value: Participants in the current study were comprised of 224 students ages 18-23 (M=19.30, SD =1.27).  This age range was selected due to the known risk for anxiety development in emerging adults.  Gender identity in the sample was comprised of 70.1% female, 25.4% male, and 4.5% other.  Racial identity consisted of 59.4% White, 27.2% Asian, 5.3% Black/African American, 4.5% multiracial, 2.7% other, and 0.9% declined to report.  Hispanic/Latino ethnicity was 8.9%.  The larger study included additional measures, that will not be analyzed in the current paper because they are not relevant to current the hypotheses.  Participants were excluded if they lacked English fluency, as the questionnaires required English proficiency in order for the measures to be valid.  There were no further exclusion criteria.  The only cost to participants was time spent participating in the study.  Additionally, participants were compensated for their time.

question.value: Participants completed baseline questionnaires within the first 10 weeks of the semester which included an assessment of stress frequency (T1).  Next, participants completed brief (~10 min) weekly online questionnaires in the 4 weeks preceding finals which included an assessment anxiety (T2).  Finally, in the two weeks following finals, participants completed a final set of online questionnaires including an assessment of AC (T3).  For the alternative model, different assessments of anxiety were implemented at T1 and T3.  A z-score composite will generate an average anxiety score for the alternative model.  Each time point implemented additional measures that were not analyzed in the current study because they are not relevant to the current set of hypotheses.  The self-report questionnaires were administered online, through the secure Qualtrics system offered through Brandeis.  Participants provided written informed consent before participation.  All procedures were approved by the Brandeis Institutional Review Board (IRB).

q13.value: Participants in the current study were comprised of 224 students.

q14.value: A power analysis for the current study, using the Monte Carlo simulation study of mediation (10,000 repetitions) in Mplus version 8, was conducted to assure adequate power (≥ 80%).  The sample size of n=224 provides adequate power (≥ 80%) for effect sizes estimated from the previous literature. Specifically, we based the effect size of the anxiety-AC (=.28) relation off an average correlation computed from past research (Melendez et al., 2017; Muris et al., 2007; Susa et al., 2012).  Similarly, both the stress-anxiety (=.30) (Gulley et al., 2016; Merz & Wolf, 2015; Riskind et al., 2013) and stress-AC (=.28) effect sizes were based on averages of correlations found in past research (Chajut & Algom, 2003; Shields et al., 2016).  The power obtained in each pathway was (≥ 80%).  To elaborate, the anxiety-AC pathway had power of 0.89, the stress-anxiety pathway had power of .99, and the stress-AC pathway power of .84.  The total indirect pathway effect size of (=.09) has power of 0.83 which provides evidence that (n=224) will be sufficient in detecting a moderate indirect effect.

question.value:
The Adolescent/Adult Life Events Questionnaire-Revised (Fassett-Carman et al., 2019), adapted from Hankin & Abramson, 2002) was administered to measure the frequency of stressors.  This survey assesses a wide range of 63 negative life events, including school/achievement problems, friendship and romantic difficulties, and family problems (e.g., “Got a bad grade on a test or assignment”). This assessment asks about how frequently an event happened within the past 3 months from 1 ‘never’ to 4 ‘always’, how stressful it was, and how controllable it felt.  In the current study, frequency will be the only measure used.  Test-retest reliability has been good (.65) (Hankin et al., 2010). In addition, it has good concurrent and predictive validity in regard to predicting increases in depression and anxiety (Hankin, 2008).
The Attentional Control Scale (ACS, (Derryberry & Reed, 2002) was administered to assess individual level of AC.  It is a 20-item self-report questionnaire that consists of two subscales – focusing (e.g., “It's very hard for me to concentrate on a difficult task when there are noises around”) and shifting (e.g., “It is easy for me to alternate between two different tasks”), that measure the degree to which individuals are able to control their attention, or suffer from lapses in attention. Participants indicate to what degree the statement describes them; 1 ‘almost never’, ‘sometimes’, 3 ‘often’, or 4 ‘always’.  Scores are calculated by averaging across items, with higher scores indicating greater attentional control.  Internal consistency has been high (α=-0.88) (Fajkowska & Derryberry, 2010) and the two factor structure fits well according to construct validity and factorial validity (Judah et al., 2014; Quigley et al., 2017).  In the current study, Cronbach’s alpha was good for focusing at T1 (α = .768) and T3 (α =.771) and shifting at T1 (α = .793) and T3 (α =.803). Overall, Cronbach’s alpha was good at T1 (α = .841) and T3 (α = .850).
The PROMIS Emotional Distress-Anxiety-Short Form (APA DSM-V research measures), was utilized to measure anxiety symptomology.  This is a 7-item measure of anxiety symptoms in the last week (e.g., “I felt worried.”), rated on a Likert scale from (1) never to (5) always.  Internal consistency for this measure is excellent (α=.93) (Pilkonis et al., 2016) and construct validity has been good (Pilkonis et al., 2016).  In the current study, Cronbach’s alpha was excellent at all time points (α = .900-.909). 
The Mood and Anxiety Symptoms Questionnaire (MASQ, (Watson et al., 1995) was administered to evaluate symptoms related to anxious arousal. The measure is comprised of 39 items that are divided into 17 items measuring anxious arousal and 22 measuring anhedonia. A sample item for anxious arousal consists of, “was trembling or shaking” and allows participants to respond from “not at all” to “extremely” in accordance to whether they experienced the symptoms during the past week. In the current study, Chronbach’s alpha for the 17 anxiety symptoms items was good at T1 and T3 (α = .847-.901).
The Penn State Worry Questionnaire (PSWQ, (Meyer et al., 1990) was implemented to measure the extent to which an individual worries. A total of 16 items consisting of statements like “My worries overwhelm me” are presented and participants are asked to rate how true the statement is for them on a 4-point Likert scale ranging from “never true” to “always true”. In the current study, Chronbach’s alpha was excellent at T1 and T3 (α = .937-.928).
An average anxiety score will be calculated by averaging the responses in T2.

Hypotheses will be tested with path models in Mplus using bootstrapping and the full information maximum likelihood (FIML) estimator, which provides unbiased parameter estimates using all available data.  Anxiety for T2 will be calculated by averaging across the four weeks. Outliers (+/- 3 SD) on each variable will be excluded from analysis.

q22.value: We will assure that subjects completed the questionnaires.  Outliers (+/- 3 SD) on each variable will be excluded from analysis.

q23.value: If data is incomplete at any of the three timepoints, the subject will not be included in the analysis.

q24.value: A purely exploratory analysis will be conducted to assess the two subscales of the ACS (focusing and shifting) separately.  Focusing tends to be slightly more effected by both stress and anxiety compared to shifting (Edwards et al., 2017; N. D. M. W. Eysenck, 1998; Gaspar & McDonald, 2018; Owens et al., 2014; Pacheco-Unguetti et al., 2010; Sadeh & Bredemeier, 2011).  Therefore, an exploration into how stress and anxiety effect the different components of AC over time may yield evidence to contribute to this potential discrepancy.  All analyses will control for age and gender.

attributes.title: Effects of Rumination on Theory of Mind in Individuals with High Traits of Depression

q1.value: Effects of Rumination on Theory of Mind in Individuals with High Traits of Depression (A Pilot Study)

q3.value:
To the best of our knowledge, no studies have explored the effect of rumination on Theory of Mind (ToM) on individuals with high traits of depression. However, there is some evidence to support a general affect of depression on ToM, but the evidence is mixed on the direction of this relationship and some studies do not find a significant relationship at all (Weightman et al 2019).

Our study design is based on Zainal and Newman's (2018) study on the effect of worry on ToM in individuals with Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD), which found that worry significantly impacts ToM performance in individuals with GAD. We will attempt to extend the manipulation of emotional state in a context more relevant to depression, rather than anxiety. We will use an induction of rumination instead of anxiety in our study to test the effect of rumination on ToM in individuals with high traits of depression.

q4.value:
H1: Active rumination will have a state-dependent effect on decoding ToM in participants with high traits of depression compared to non-depressed controls, but not active relaxation.

H2: Active rumination will lead to less accurate decoding ToM in participants with high traits of depression compared to non-depressed controls, but not active relaxation.

H3: Active rumination will lead to less reasoning ToM and for both of its affective and cognitive subcomponents compared to non-depressed controls, but not active relaxation.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Our design is a 2 (Trait Group: high trait depression, low trait depression) by 2 (Emotional State: Rumination, Relaxation) between-group block design.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited through an undergraduate research pool. Participants may be compensated .5 bonus credit in applicable psychology courses through the university. 

Additional participants will be recruited through reddit subforums such as the subreddit r/samplesize. These participants will not be given monetary compensation or otherwise. Subjects recruited from this platform will be required to be 18 or older.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 180 participants based on a G Power analysis for ANOVAs with fixed effects, special, main effects and interactions, a power of .80, .25 effect size, and 4 groups. We will recruit more than 180 participants based on a 50% LexTALE cutoff. Scores of 50% or above will be covaried during analysis.

question.value:
The MASC consists of a 15-minute video depicting a group of four friends having conversations and dinner. The video pauses throughout and participants are presented with questions in multiple choice format about the feelings and intentions of different characters. Answers are grouped in four categories: (1) correct inference of mental states, (2) no inference of mental states, (3) not enough inference of mental states, and (4) excessive inference of mental states. For example, in the first video Michael knocks on Sandra's door. She answers and greets him. Then, Michael compliments her hair and she thanks him. The video pauses and participants are asked "What is Sandra feeling?" with the option of choosing among four answers: (a) her hair does not look that nice, (b) she is pleased about his compliment, (c) she is exasperated about Michael coming on too strong, or (d) she is flattered but somewhat taken by surprise.

The RMIE consists of a decoding task where people view 18 images of pictures cropped to display a 15cm by 6cm portion of faces centered around the eyes. Participants are asked to select one of four words, one correct and three distractors, that accurately describes the person in the picture's mental state (i.e., pensive, doubtful).

Overall Theory of Mind reasoning will be measured by assigning absolute scores for each error (less, no ToM, and excessive) using the MASC. Affective ToM will be measured with the percentage of correct scores on questions that ask what the person in the MASC is feeling. Cognitive ToM will be measured with the percentage of correct scores on questions that ask what the person in the MASC is thinking. Questions in the MASC will also be categorized as positively, neutrally, and negatively valenced. Decoding ToM will be measured using percentage of correct scores on the RMIE task. Emotions for each set of eyes in the RMIE will be categorized as positively, neutrally, or negatively valenced.

Traits of social anxiety will be measured using the Social Interaction Anxiety Scale (SIAS) and a cutoff score of 34 will be used based on recommended scoring cutoffs for high levels of social anxiety. Scores of 34 or above will be covaried during the ANCOVA analysis.

Traits of generalized anxiety disorder will be measured using the Generalized Anxiety Disorder Questionnaire-IV (GAD-Q-IV) using a cutoff score of 7.67 based on previous literature (Moore et al. 2013). Persons who score 7.67 or higher will be covaried.

Traits of depression will be measured using the Depression Anxiety Stress Scales-Weekly (DASS-Weekly) using a cutoff score of 14 based on recommended scoring cutoffs which indicate moderate depression. Participants who score 14 or greater will be considered in the high trait depression group and those who score 6 or less will be in the low depression group.
Traits of rumination will be measured using the Self-Critical Rumination Scale (SCRS) using a cutoff score 30 points. Scores of 30 or higher will be considered excessive rumination.

Executive function will be measured using a computerized stroop task. Performance on this task will be covaried during analysis.

First we will conduct a series of four 2x2 ANOVAs investigating the impact of emotional state (rumination vs. relaxation) and traits of depression (high vs. low) on ToM decoding and overall reasoning accuracy, affective reasoning, and cognitive reasoning.

Next, we will conduct a series of four ANCOVAs investigating the impact of emotional state (worry vs. relaxation) on traits of generalized anxiety (high vs. low) on ToM decoding and overall reasoning accuracy, affective reasoning, and cognitive reasoning, controlling for gender (male, female, other), English proficiency, social anxiety as measured by scores on the SIAS (high cutoff scores), Generalized Anxiety Disorder as measured by the GAD-Q-IV (high cutoff scores), and medication status as based on a self-report question in demographics of whether the participant has taken or is currently taking medication for anxiety, depression, or other mental health issues (yes or no) as covariates.

registration_responses.q1: Effects of Rumination on Theory of Mind in Individuals with High Traits of Depression (A Pilot Study)
registration_responses.q3:
To the best of our knowledge, no studies have explored the effect of rumination on Theory of Mind (ToM) on individuals with high traits of depression. However, there is some evidence to support a general affect of depression on ToM, but the evidence is mixed on the direction of this relationship and some studies do not find a significant relationship at all (Weightman et al 2019).

Our study design is based on Zainal and Newman's (2018) study on the effect of worry on ToM in individuals with Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD), which found that worry significantly impacts ToM performance in individuals with GAD. We will attempt to extend the manipulation of emotional state in a context more relevant to depression, rather than anxiety. We will use an induction of rumination instead of anxiety in our study to test the effect of rumination on ToM in individuals with high traits of depression.
registration_responses.q4:
H1: Active rumination will have a state-dependent effect on decoding ToM in participants with high traits of depression compared to non-depressed controls, but not active relaxation.

H2: Active rumination will lead to less accurate decoding ToM in participants with high traits of depression compared to non-depressed controls, but not active relaxation.

H3: Active rumination will lead to less reasoning ToM and for both of its affective and cognitive subcomponents compared to non-depressed controls, but not active relaxation.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: Our target sample size is 180 participants based on a G Power analysis for ANOVAs with fixed effects, special, main effects and interactions, a power of .80, .25 effect size, and 4 groups. We will recruit more than 180 participants based on a 50% LexTALE cutoff. Scores of 50% or above will be covaried during analysis.
registration_responses.q8.question: Our design is a 2 (Trait Group: high trait depression, low trait depression) by 2 (Emotional State: Rumination, Relaxation) between-group block design.
registration_responses.q12.question:
Participants will be recruited through an undergraduate research pool. Participants may be compensated .5 bonus credit in applicable psychology courses through the university. 

Additional participants will be recruited through reddit subforums such as the subreddit r/samplesize. These participants will not be given monetary compensation or otherwise. Subjects recruited from this platform will be required to be 18 or older.
registration_responses.q17.question:
The MASC consists of a 15-minute video depicting a group of four friends having conversations and dinner. The video pauses throughout and participants are presented with questions in multiple choice format about the feelings and intentions of different characters. Answers are grouped in four categories: (1) correct inference of mental states, (2) no inference of mental states, (3) not enough inference of mental states, and (4) excessive inference of mental states. For example, in the first video Michael knocks on Sandra's door. She answers and greets him. Then, Michael compliments her hair and she thanks him. The video pauses and participants are asked "What is Sandra feeling?" with the option of choosing among four answers: (a) her hair does not look that nice, (b) she is pleased about his compliment, (c) she is exasperated about Michael coming on too strong, or (d) she is flattered but somewhat taken by surprise.

The RMIE consists of a decoding task where people view 18 images of pictures cropped to display a 15cm by 6cm portion of faces centered around the eyes. Participants are asked to select one of four words, one correct and three distractors, that accurately describes the person in the picture's mental state (i.e., pensive, doubtful).

Overall Theory of Mind reasoning will be measured by assigning absolute scores for each error (less, no ToM, and excessive) using the MASC. Affective ToM will be measured with the percentage of correct scores on questions that ask what the person in the MASC is feeling. Cognitive ToM will be measured with the percentage of correct scores on questions that ask what the person in the MASC is thinking. Questions in the MASC will also be categorized as positively, neutrally, and negatively valenced. Decoding ToM will be measured using percentage of correct scores on the RMIE task. Emotions for each set of eyes in the RMIE will be categorized as positively, neutrally, or negatively valenced.

Traits of social anxiety will be measured using the Social Interaction Anxiety Scale (SIAS) and a cutoff score of 34 will be used based on recommended scoring cutoffs for high levels of social anxiety. Scores of 34 or above will be covaried during the ANCOVA analysis.

Traits of generalized anxiety disorder will be measured using the Generalized Anxiety Disorder Questionnaire-IV (GAD-Q-IV) using a cutoff score of 7.67 based on previous literature (Moore et al. 2013). Persons who score 7.67 or higher will be covaried.

Traits of depression will be measured using the Depression Anxiety Stress Scales-Weekly (DASS-Weekly) using a cutoff score of 14 based on recommended scoring cutoffs which indicate moderate depression. Participants who score 14 or greater will be considered in the high trait depression group and those who score 6 or less will be in the low depression group.
Traits of rumination will be measured using the Self-Critical Rumination Scale (SCRS) using a cutoff score 30 points. Scores of 30 or higher will be considered excessive rumination.

Executive function will be measured using a computerized stroop task. Performance on this task will be covaried during analysis.
registration_responses.q19.question:
First we will conduct a series of four 2x2 ANOVAs investigating the impact of emotional state (rumination vs. relaxation) and traits of depression (high vs. low) on ToM decoding and overall reasoning accuracy, affective reasoning, and cognitive reasoning.

Next, we will conduct a series of four ANCOVAs investigating the impact of emotional state (worry vs. relaxation) on traits of generalized anxiety (high vs. low) on ToM decoding and overall reasoning accuracy, affective reasoning, and cognitive reasoning, controlling for gender (male, female, other), English proficiency, social anxiety as measured by scores on the SIAS (high cutoff scores), Generalized Anxiety Disorder as measured by the GAD-Q-IV (high cutoff scores), and medication status as based on a self-report question in demographics of whether the participant has taken or is currently taking medication for anxiety, depression, or other mental health issues (yes or no) as covariates.

attributes.title: #HappyAnniversary: Gender Differences in Spouses' and Partners' Milestone Greetings on Twitter
attributes.description: A class project for Research Methods (HDFS 3390) at Texas Tech University in Fall 2019. Students will content-analyze Twitter tweets of anniversary greetings, so that gender differences in the content of these tweets can be investigated.

q1.value: #HappyAnniversary: Gender Differences in Spouses' and Partners' Milestone Greetings on Twitter

q3.value: A class project for Research Methods (HDFS 3390) at Texas Tech University in Fall 2019. Students will content-analyze Twitter tweets of anniversary greetings, so that gender differences in the content of these tweets can be investigated.

q4.value: Barbieri, Ronzano, and Saggion (2016) cluster-analyzed emojis commonly used on Twitter, yielding groupings such as "things are good" (thumbs up, OK sign, sun glasses); heart and smiley faces; alcoholic beverages and other food; and emotions such as laughing and crying. We compared emojis and verbal references (e.g., "my best friend") in men's and women's Twitter tweets marking a wedding or relationship anniversary. Based on studies showing that women tend to express vulnerable emotions, including love, more readily than do men (e.g., Gonzalez & Koestner, 2006), we predict that women's (relative to men's) tweets will more frequently feature heart/smiley and laughing/crying emojis. In contrast, we expect men to make more frequent use of "things are good" and alcohol/food emojis.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The design is archival/content analysis. Judges have coded Twitter tweets for emojis and verbal references used in tweeters' delivery of wedding/relationship anniversary greetings to their spouse/partner.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: The data were collected in September-October 2019. Registration is taking place in March 2020, before primary analyses of men's and women's use of emojis in different clusters (Barbieri et al., 2016) have been conducted.

question.value: Students in an undergraduate research methods class coded Twitter tweets containing wedding/relationship anniversary greetings. Characteristics coded are shown in attached document. Each student was given a unique date in either September or October 2019, and was instructed to code all tweets from that date that could be located via the hashtag "#HappyAnniversary." Students whose day contained few such tweets could request a new day. Anniversary tweets other than those from one spouse/romantic partner to another (e.g., a child wishing his or her parents a happy anniversary) were excluded.

q14.value: One day's worth of tweets (approximately 15 per student) was deemed by the instructor to be an appropriate workload for the particular assignment.

question.value: Measured variables are listed in the attached instruction sheet for student coders.

Student coders originally listed emojis used in each tweet, in open-ended fashion (e.g., heart, smiley face). An undergraduate student assistant in Spring 2020 (who was in the Fall 2019 research methods class and thus one of the original data collectors) has assigned the listed emojis from all the data collectors to categories from Barbieri et al. (2016), under the supervision of the faculty member who taught the Fall 2019 methods class.

Men and women tweeters will be compared on use/non-use of various types of emojis (e.g., heart/smiley face emojis, alcohol/food emojis) via chi-square tests. Men's and women's use of photos in their tweets (none, wedding photo, current photo, or both kinds of photos) will also be analyzed via chi-square. Count variables (e.g., number of emojis used) will compared for men and women using t-tests. Exploratory comparisons of emoji usage by other demographic characteristics (e.g., age, race-ethnicity) will also be conducted.

q20.value: As described earlier, we will place the original emojis (e.g., heart, champagne bottle) into higher-order categories (operationalized via Barbieri et al.'s, 2016, clusters).

q22.value: Most variables are demographic or absent/present in nature (i.e., whether or not a given type of emoji was used), so outliers are not expected.

q23.value: Missing data are common on some of the demographic variables. For example, students could only code for (estimated) age if the tweeter included a current photo in the tweet. Tweets with no photo would thus be considered missing on age. Analyses will simply use all the cases that are available for a given set of variables.

q24.value: Exploratory comparisons of emoji use by other demographic categories (e.g., age, race-ethnicity) will be conducted.

attributes.title: Guizhi decoction for allergic rhinitis: protocol for a systematic review and meta analysis
attributes.description: Allergic rhinitis (AR) is a common symptomatic, inflammatory and immunological disorder of nasal mucosa results from allergen exposure triggered IgE response. Epidemiology of allergic rhinitis varies according to different factors like genetic constitution, racial differences, socio-economic conditions, chances of exposure to different allergens, sex, growth stages. AR shows high prevalence among developed countries. AR is managed with first and second anti histamines(56%), intra nasal corticosteroids (25%) and mast cell stabilizers (19%). Prolonged usage of these medications are necessary in beating the disease as far as the recurrence is concerned. This may lead to numerous serious health hazards. Studies have shown that negative effects of sedative anti-histamines last to the succeeding day disturbing the day time performance.

q1.value: Guizhi decoction for allergic rhinitis: protocol for a systematic review and meta analysis

q2.value: Shasha Yang, Qinwei Fu, Jing Wu, Qinxiu Zhang, Limin Wang, Hua Deng, Xianfeng Yao

q3.value: Allergic rhinitis (AR) is a common symptomatic, inflammatory and immunological disorder of nasal mucosa results from allergen exposure triggered IgE response. Epidemiology of allergic rhinitis varies according to different factors like genetic constitution, racial differences, socio-economic conditions, chances of exposure to different allergens, sex, growth stages. AR shows high prevalence among developed countries. AR is managed with first and second anti histamines(56%), intra nasal corticosteroids (25%) and mast cell stabilizers (19%). Prolonged usage of these medications are necessary in beating the disease as far as the recurrence is concerned. This may lead to numerous serious health hazards. Studies have shown that negative effects of sedative anti-histamines last to the succeeding day disturbing the day time performance. Traditional Chinese medicine in the treatment of allergic rhinitis has done a lot of research, the effect is significant. There are no SR or protocol on the Guizhi decoction for allergic rhinitis. Therefore, research on it is needed.

q4.value:
1. Guizhi decoction is effective for treatment of patients with allergic rhinitis.
2. How does the efficacy of Guizhi decoction compare to that with Western medicine therapies alone, other TCM therapies alone, blank control, placebo control and other interventions? 
3. There are some moderating variables associated with treatment efficacy in studies of Guizhi decoction for patients with the allergic rhinitis.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

q7.value:
Three reviewers searched the online databases listed above and recorded the titles and abstracts of all the articles.
Three evaluators assessed the eligibility of these articles and made decisions on every research (inclusion or exclusion) independently. If they did not reach the same decision, the concerned articles were discussed with a fourth reviewer.
Three reviewers extracted data independently from each study.
Differences regarding the extracted data were resolved after discussion with a fourth reviewer.
Three authors of our review team will independently assess the methodological quality of included trials, and consensus will be reached by discussion with a third party in case of discrepancy.

The methodological quality of RCTs will be assessed according to the risk of bias tool described in the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions [Higgins JPT 2009]. Six elements will be assessed: random sequence generation, allocation concealment, blinding of outcome assessors, incomplete outcome data, free of selective reporting, and other bias. Disagreements will be resolved by discussion with a third party.

question.value:
1. Anticipated start date: 12/01/2020;

2. Anticipated completion date: 24/04/2020;

3.Review question: ①. 1. Is the Guizhi decoction an effective treatment for patiens with allergic rhinitis?
                ②. How does the efficacy of Guizhi decoction compare to that with acupuncture, having western medicines, blank control, placebo control and other interventions?
                ③. What moderating variables are associated with treatment effectiveness in studies of the Guizhi decoction for patients with allergic rhinitis? 

4. Searches: English databases including PubMed, Embase, Cochrane Library and Chinese databases including CNKI, Wanfang, VIP databases will be searched. The research will start following the PRISMA protocol.
The terms used in the search will follow the rules of the Medical Subject Headings (MeSH) and the question that guided the search was based on the PICOS strategy (participants, interventions, comparison, results and studies). search strategy information can be found in the attached PDF document (link provided below).
One month will be allocated for data collection and one month for article analysis.
Retrieval time is from the inception dates of the databases to 23 Feb, 2020.
We also considered the alternative terms and spellings for keywords.
In addition, the references of initially included literature were traced back to achieve a comprehensive search. English and Chinese language were included.

5. Condition or domain being studied: Allergic rhinitis (AR) is a common symptomatic, inflammatory and immunological disorder of nasal mucosa results from allergen exposure triggered IgE response. Epidemiology of allergic rhinitis varies according to different factors like genetic constitution, racial differences, socio-economic conditions, chances of exposure to different allergens, sex, growth stages. AR shows high prevalence among developed countries. AR is managed with first and second anti histamines(56%), intra nasal corticosteroids (25%) and mast cell stabilizers (19%). Prolonged usage of these medications are necessary in beating the disease as far as the recurrence is concerned. This may lead to numerous serious health hazards. Studies have shown that negative effects of sedative anti-histamines last to the succeeding day disturbing the day time performance. Traditional Chinese medicine in the treatment of allergic rhinitis has done a lot of research, the effect is significant. There are no SR or protocol on the Guizhi decoction for allergic rhinitis. Therefore, research on it is needed.

6.Participants/population: Participants with all types of allergic rhinitis (including intermittent allergic rhinitis and persistent allergic rhinitis) regardless of gender, age, etiology, ethnic group, severity, diagnosed with specific criteria (i.e. mention any one of criteria for diagnosis of allergic rhinitis) are eligible for inclusion. Complicated with asthma, nasosinusitis are excluded.

7. Intervention(s), exposure(s): Treatment of the Guizhi decoction, including dosage forms of pieces of traditional Chinese medicine, boil-free granule of Traditional Chinese medicine, Chinese patent drug and other available forms.

8. Comparator(s)/control: Including acupuncture, western medicines, blank control, placebo control and other interventions. Interventions in the experimental group were not included.

9. Types of study to be included: We will include randomised controlled trials (RCTs), published and unpublished, in English and Chinese.

10. Main outcome(s): ①Total Nasal Symptom Score (TNSS) and four key symptoms' scores;
                   ②Rhinitis Quality of Life Questionnaire (RQLQ); 
                   ③VAS score;
                   ④Total effective rate;
⑤Score for signs and symptoms;
⑥The improvement of disease classification.

11. Additional outcome(s): ① TNNSS;
                       ②Laboratory index, eg. IgE, IL;
③Recurrence rate;
④Time when the symptoms disappear;
⑤Frequency of seizure;
⑥The case of drug reduction.

12. Data extraction (selection and coding): Three reviewers searched the online databases listed above and recorded the titles and abstracts of all the articles.
Three evaluators assessed the eligibility of these articles and made decisions on every research (inclusion or exclusion) independently. If they did not reach the same decision, the concerned articles were discussed with a fourth reviewer.
Three reviewers extracted data independently from each study.
Differences regarding the extracted data were resolved after discussion with a fourth reviewer.

13.Risk of bias (quality) assessment: Three authors of our review team will independently assess the methodological quality of included trials, and consensus will be reached by discussion with a third party in case of discrepancy.
The methodological quality of RCTs will be assessed according to the risk of bias tool described in the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions [Higgins JPT 2009]. Six elements will be assessed: random sequence generation, allocation concealment, blinding of outcome assessors, incomplete outcome data, free of selective reporting, and other bias. Disagreements will be resolved by discussion with a third party.

14. Strategy for data synthesis: Statistical analyses will be performed using RevMan 5.3 software (The Cochrane Collaboration).
- Pooled risk ratio (RR) with 95% confidence interval (CI) of dichotomous outcomes will be used to report effect estimate.
- Continuous data will be presented as mean difference (MD) with 95% CI. If different measurement scales are used, standardized mean difference (SMD) will be performed to analyze continuous data.
If required data are not reported, we will try to obtain data from corresponding author.
Heterogeneity will be assessed using both the χ² test and the I² statistic, and we will consider an I² value greater than 50% indicative of substantial heterogeneity.
- For I²<50%, a fixed-effect model is used.
- For I² >=50%, a random-effect model is applied.
If data permit, we plan to exclude some trials that contribuite most to the heterogeneity to see whether the result change or not.
We will also use a summary of findings table to present the main findings using GRADEpro software (The Cochrane Collaboration). Funnel plots will be generated to detect publication bias if more than 10 trials are identified to report the same outcomes. If appropriate, we will use cumulative meta-analyses. Results of meta-analyses will be visualized by forest plots. In addition, we will conduct trial sequential analysis to evaluate the meta-analyses for primary outcomes, which can reveal the required information size and potentially false results in a meta-analysis. Intention-to-treat analysis will be applied for primary outcome, if missing data from the original trials are available.

15. Analysis of subgroups or subsets: If data permitted, we plan to conduct subgroup analyses for different groups, including:
Different age of patients
Different severity of disease
Different regimen applied
Different treat time
Different acupoints selected
Combined with other interventions or not.

16. Type and method of review: intervention; Meta-analysis; Prevention; Systematic review.

17. Health area of the review: Complementary therapies; Allergy; Public health; ENT; 

18. Languages of the review: English and Chinese;

19. Dissemination plans: In addition to producing a report, a paper will be submitted to a journal in this field.

registration_responses.q3: Allergic rhinitis (AR) is a common symptomatic, inflammatory and immunological disorder of nasal mucosa results from allergen exposure triggered IgE response. AR shows high prevalence among developed countries. AR is managed with first and second anti histamines(56%), intra nasal corticosteroids (25%) and mast cell stabilizers (19%). Therefore, research on it is needed.

attributes.title: A View from Another Lens: Investigating the Misinformation Effect in 360° Virtual Reality

q1.value: A View from Another Lens: Investigating the Misinformation Effect in 360° Virtual Reality

q3.value:
For over 40 years, researchers have attempted to explain the misinformation effect (ME) – memory alterations due to misleading post-event information [8]. While research has examined this robust effect in laboratory settings, this phenomenon can be observed in real-world settings. A prominent criminal case involved the wrongful conviction of Ivan Henry, who was sentenced to 27 years in prison for multiple counts of rape [11]. Evidence presented during the trial included a falsified photograph of a physical line-up, which portrayed three officers putting the supposed suspect in a headlock while smiling with surrounding men handcuffed and dressed in plain clothing. This photograph was the driving force which led to his conviction, along with a lack of medical and forensic evidence and faulty instructions to the jury. Victims in this case were misinformed by the exposure to this photograph, and 6 of 11 women identified Henry as the rapist [2]. Moreover, the trial judge incorrectly told the jury that Henry’s reluctance to participate in this police line-up implied guilt [11]. These errors would not have occurred in the presence of an amicus curiae, or a lawyer to facilitate Henry with the legal process. Not only is this case a solid exemplar of the misinformation effect, but is also a threat to Henry’s Charter rights. 
The ME paradigm commonly consists of three phases: individuals first witness an event, receive post-event misinformation, and are then tested on their memory of the event [6]. Seminal research conducted by Loftus and Palmer (1974) demonstrated this effect by asking participants to watch a scene of a car accident before answering questions regarding their recollection of the event. Researchers found that participants who were asked about the two cars that “smashed” into each other were more likely to report seeing non-existent broken glass than those who were asked about the two cars that “bumped” into each other [10]. Similar findings have further supported ME, with people mistaking stop signs as yield signs, hammers as screwdrivers, straight hair as curly and a clean-shaven man as having a mustache, all as a result of suggestive post-event misinformation [10]. These findings provide compelling evidence that memories can be altered with relatively simple ME manipulations.
	Conventional methods of assessing the ME have involved the use of photographs [5] and standard two-dimensional (2-D) videos [4]. However, not much research has looked at the potential effects of presentation modality (e.g., photographs vs. videos) on the ME. One recent study sought to determine whether memory accuracy for videos and slideshows was differentially affected by misinformation [6]. Although results indicated a ME in both formats, susceptibility to the ME was similar across formats. Considering that encoding for details is typically stronger for a live event (i.e., real objects) compared to a video or photographs [12], effects observed with conventional ME stimuli may not accurately represent the ME in real life contexts. Virtual Reality (VR), which allows individuals to view and interact with detailed simulated environments, may allow researchers to examine the ME with greater ecological validity. However, it is unclear whether and how the ME manifests in VR? Kenchel (2019) noted that certain informative features which may be present in real-life contexts may not have been visible on a computer screen. Thus, we need research involving the ME in Virtual Reality. 
	Virtual Reality (VR) is a computer-based environment that allows one to explore and interact with a simulated world [13]. In its most common form, individuals experience a 360° view of a virtual environment while wearing a Head Mounted Display (HMD). Recent work from an unpublished honours thesis has investigated a classic ME paradigm [9] using a 3-D setting in VR [7]. In this study, participants explored a 3-D environment of the Loftus car accident scenario and were then asked questions about the speed of the cars, the presence of broken glass, etc. Replicating the original result, participants who received misinformation (the cars “smashed”) reported higher speed estimates.  However, no other significant differences were found for the presence of broken glass, or for which car was at fault. While the ME was not found to increase in VR, the author notes that these findings were based on an underpowered and non-diverse sample [7]. Aside from this, only one other study has investigated the ME with VR, and though this study found a ME, it was also likely underpowered [4]. These inconclusive results warrant further investigation of the ME in VR. Additionally, no studies have compared the ME in VR in other formats.
Past research has relied on materials that may lack ecological validity (i.e., slideshows, 2-D videos). Establishing an ecologically valid measure of VR on the ME may provide a better representation of ME in real life. Additionally, if the vividness of VR reduces ME relative to photos and videos, there may be practical real-world applications (e.g., police interviewing via reconstruction of scenes in VR). The present study seeks to investigate the viability of a VR-ME paradigm, as well as differences in the ME between three modalities: slideshow, two-dimensional (2-D) video and 360° VR video in an HMD. The proposed study will consist of three pilot experiments and one main experiment.
The proposed study has implications for both eyewitness memory researchers (i.e., the development of materials with higher ecological validity). In criminal cases, misinformation (e.g., leading questions, co-witness contamination) may lead to a false eyewitness testimony. Hence, examining how the differences between stimuli affect an eyewitness’ susceptibility to memory error is important. On a theoretical level, many studies rely on pallid materials in laboratory settings [7]. In comparison to two-dimensional videos and slideshows, VR could be a proxy for a real-life setting and serve as an additional modality to future research with ME paradigms. This study will serve as potential validation for the use of VR with the ME paradigm, and will introduce opportunities for further exploration in this field of research. Practical applications from this research could establish a new method of assessing ME using an ecologically valid scenario, such as recreating crime and accident scenes, or demonstrating an eyewitness’s ability to recognize perpetrators in a police line-up [1].

q4.value:
The following hypotheses apply to the main experiment for this study:

H1: Main effect of stimulus on memory errors: Slideshow > 2-D video > 360-degree video..  

H2: Main effect of post-event information, where memory errors due to misinformation will be greater than no information.

H3: Interaction between stimulus and post-event information; the difference between misinformation and no information will be largest in the slideshow condition, and smallest in the 360-degree video condition. If an overall difference is observed, additional t-tests will be conducted to further analyze the differences between stimuli based on a difference score of post-event information (misinformation, no misinformation)

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: There is no additional blinding in this study.

question.value:
Pilot Experiment 1: The purpose of this experiment is to test and validate new stimuli, which consist of a custom-made video of a thief in a house and questions about critical video details. We intend to determine which critical video details are most appropriate for use in our main study. By “appropriate,” we mean items for which memory performance is average (i.e., away from floor and ceiling to permit observable effects in either direction). The secondary objective of this pilot is to test for differences in memory between pictures and two-dimensional (2-D) video. 
Pilot Experiment 2: This pilot will be identical to the first, except that instead of viewing a slideshow or 2-D video, participants will view a 360° video in a HMD. The goal will be the same—to determine which critical details elicit an appropriate level of memory performance. 
Pilot experiment 3: The purpose of this experiment is to determine whether our new stimuli can be used to elicit a misinformation effect using the standard 2-D video paradigm. For each participant, a “misinformation effect score” will be calculated as the difference in memory performance on misinformed items and items for which no information (correct or incorrect) was presented. 
Main experiment: The main experiment will compare the ME in VR to conventional materials using a 3 (Stimulus: 360-degree video, standard 2-D video, slideshow) by 2 (Post-event information: misinformation, no misinformation) between-within subjects design. Post-event information will be presented as a vignette, which includes a series of 36 statements (final # to be determined via pilot testing for appropriate critical details).
