question.value:
The main experiment will compare the ME in VR to conventional materials using a 3 (Stimulus: 360-degree video, standard 2-D video, slideshow) by 2 (Post-event information: misinformation, no information) between-within subjects design. 

The manipulated and dependent variables are listed as follows: 

IV1: Stimulus condition (Between-subjects)
-Slideshow: 
-2-D video:
-360-degree video: 

IV2: Post-Event Information (Within-subjects)
-Misinformation: Vignette statement is not consistent with the critical detail shown in the video
-No information: No vignette is presented for the critical detail

DV1: Memory errors: For each Format X Information cell, the proportion of incorrect responses on the 4-alternative-forced-choice memory questionnaire will be calculated. 

DV2: Misinformation scores: For each participant a misinformation score will be calculated by subtracting the amount of errors for “No information” items from the amount of errors for “Misinformation” items.

DV 3: Confidence scores: Confidence will be measured on a 5-point scale from 1 (not at all confident) to 5 (very confident), which will correspond to each answer participants provide on the memory questionnaire. A mean confidence score will be calculated for each question. 

DV 4: ITC- Sense of Presence Inventory (ITC-SOPI) Scale:  The ITC-SOPI is a 44-item cross media presence questionnaire used to examine four facets of media experience: Sense of Physical Space, Engagement, Ecological Validity and Negative Effects. Each subscale is comprised of 5-points ranging from 1 (strongly disagree) to 5 (strongly agree). Items will be scored based off a mean average for each of the 4 aspects of media experience.

Pilot experiment 1: We will estimate memory accuracy for all potential critical details (via estimating the proportion of correct answers for each critical detail and computing 95% CIs on those proportions) and compare memory accuracy across formats (2D video vs. slideshow) via independent-samples t test. Pilot Study 1 will serve to ensure that memory items are within an acceptable range of memory performance for 2D video and slideshow formats, and will also serve as a preliminary comparison of general memory performance across these formats. By “acceptable” memory performance, we mean not too low/high (to avoid floor/ceiling effects and allow room for memory performance to shift). As preliminary criteria for “acceptable”, we will consider a critical detail acceptable if the lower-bound 95% CI > 30% and the higher-bound 95% CI < 70% (though we may relax these criteria if too few critical details meet our criteria).
Pilot experiment 2: Data will be analyzed via mean scores of memory accuracy from the memory test. As in Pilot Study 1, we will estimate the proportion of participants that get each memory item correct and computing 95% CIs on those proportions. Like Pilot Study 1, Pilot Study 2 will serve to ensure that memory items are within an acceptable range of memory performance for 360-degree video.
Pilot experiment 3: A one sample t-test will be conducted on misinformation effect scores to assess whether there is an overall ME.
Main study: We will assess the magnitude of the ME in each condition, and potential differences in the ME, by analyzing memory errors using a 3 (Stimulus condition: Slideshow, 2D Video, 360-degree video) X 2 (Post-event information: No information, misinformation) mixed ANOVA. If a significant interaction is observed, we will compare the ME (Misinformed item memory errors – No information item memory errors) across stimulus conditions via pairwise independent-samples t tests. If there is a main effect of Post-event information or an interaction, we will also conduct one-sample t tests in each stimulus condition comparing the misinformation effect in each condition with 0. 

For all pairwise/follow-up comparisons, we will control for familywise Type I error rates by using Holm-Bonferroni correction. We will supplement all NHST analyses with Bayesian analogues (i.e., Bayesian ANOVAs and t tests using “default” priors). We will also consider later exploratory analyses using more complicated models (i.e., multilevel models to examine item-level effects). Finally, we may also conduct exploratory analyses including the “Consistent information” statements (though these are not of primary interest for our main analyses)

Exploratory Analyses:

We may also conduct exploratory ROC curve analyses, plotting correct answers against errors (misinformation vs. other errors) across multiple levels of response bias (represented by different levels of confidence given with answers), in order to see whether the stimulus conditions differentially promote ability to discriminate between correct and incorrect answers. 

To examine the relationship between memory accuracy and presence in VR, we will correlate mean test scores with scores from the ITC-Sense of Presence Inventory (ITC-SOPI). 

We will also compare scores of ecological validity, engagement, negative effects and sense of physical space across formats, and tentatively predict a main effect of format, such that 
360-degree presence> 2-D video presence> slideshow presence. This analysis will serve as a quasi-manipulation check that the formats we used do indeed differ in the kind of experience they offer participants.

Regardless of whether the effect of format on memory errors/ME is significant, we may also conduct exploratory mediation analyses of Format -> X -> Memory errors/ME, where X will be each of the subscales of the ITC (Presence, Engagement, Ecological Validity, Negative Effects). These analyses will be exploratory for two reasons: First, though we broadly hypothesize that some aspect of VR might explain our predicted results, we have no predictions as to the specific mechanism. Second, mediation analyses typically require larger sample sizes, and it is unlikely that we will achieve adequate power for such analyses with our planned sample size.

Because the ITC-SOPI applies more directly to VR formats, we may conduct an additional mediation analysis identical to the above, but only in the 360-degree video condition. Again, we have no predictions as to the specific mechanism.

registration_responses.q1: A View from Another Lens: Investigating the Misinformation Effect in 360° Virtual Reality
registration_responses.q3:
For over 40 years, researchers have attempted to explain the misinformation effect (ME) – memory alterations due to misleading post-event information [8]. While research has examined this robust effect in laboratory settings, this phenomenon can be observed in real-world settings. A prominent criminal case involved the wrongful conviction of Ivan Henry, who was sentenced to 27 years in prison for multiple counts of rape [11]. Evidence presented during the trial included a falsified photograph of a physical line-up, which portrayed three officers putting the supposed suspect in a headlock while smiling with surrounding men handcuffed and dressed in plain clothing. This photograph was the driving force which led to his conviction, along with a lack of medical and forensic evidence and faulty instructions to the jury. Victims in this case were misinformed by the exposure to this photograph, and 6 of 11 women identified Henry as the rapist [2]. Moreover, the trial judge incorrectly told the jury that Henry’s reluctance to participate in this police line-up implied guilt [11]. These errors would not have occurred in the presence of an amicus curiae, or a lawyer to facilitate Henry with the legal process. Not only is this case a solid exemplar of the misinformation effect, but is also a threat to Henry’s Charter rights. 
The ME paradigm commonly consists of three phases: individuals first witness an event, receive post-event misinformation, and are then tested on their memory of the event [6]. Seminal research conducted by Loftus and Palmer (1974) demonstrated this effect by asking participants to watch a scene of a car accident before answering questions regarding their recollection of the event. Researchers found that participants who were asked about the two cars that “smashed” into each other were more likely to report seeing non-existent broken glass than those who were asked about the two cars that “bumped” into each other [10]. Similar findings have further supported ME, with people mistaking stop signs as yield signs, hammers as screwdrivers, straight hair as curly and a clean-shaven man as having a mustache, all as a result of suggestive post-event misinformation [10]. These findings provide compelling evidence that memories can be altered with relatively simple ME manipulations.
	Conventional methods of assessing the ME have involved the use of photographs [5] and standard two-dimensional (2-D) videos [4]. However, not much research has looked at the potential effects of presentation modality (e.g., photographs vs. videos) on the ME. One recent study sought to determine whether memory accuracy for videos and slideshows was differentially affected by misinformation [6]. Although results indicated a ME in both formats, susceptibility to the ME was similar across formats. Considering that encoding for details is typically stronger for a live event (i.e., real objects) compared to a video or photographs [12], effects observed with conventional ME stimuli may not accurately represent the ME in real life contexts. Virtual Reality (VR), which allows individuals to view and interact with detailed simulated environments, may allow researchers to examine the ME with greater ecological validity. However, it is unclear whether and how the ME manifests in VR? Kenchel (2019) noted that certain informative features which may be present in real-life contexts may not have been visible on a computer screen. Thus, we need research involving the ME in Virtual Reality. 
	Virtual Reality (VR) is a computer-based environment that allows one to explore and interact with a simulated world [13]. In its most common form, individuals experience a 360° view of a virtual environment while wearing a Head Mounted Display (HMD). Recent work from an unpublished honours thesis has investigated a classic ME paradigm [9] using a 3-D setting in VR [7]. In this study, participants explored a 3-D environment of the Loftus car accident scenario and were then asked questions about the speed of the cars, the presence of broken glass, etc. Replicating the original result, participants who received misinformation (the cars “smashed”) reported higher speed estimates.  However, no other significant differences were found for the presence of broken glass, or for which car was at fault. While the ME was not found to increase in VR, the author notes that these findings were based on an underpowered and non-diverse sample [7]. Aside from this, only one other study has investigated the ME with VR, and though this study found a ME, it was also likely underpowered [4]. These inconclusive results warrant further investigation of the ME in VR. Additionally, no studies have compared the ME in VR in other formats.
Past research has relied on materials that may lack ecological validity (i.e., slideshows, 2-D videos). Establishing an ecologically valid measure of VR on the ME may provide a better representation of ME in real life. Additionally, if the vividness of VR reduces ME relative to photos and videos, there may be practical real-world applications (e.g., police interviewing via reconstruction of scenes in VR). The present study seeks to investigate the viability of a VR-ME paradigm, as well as differences in the ME between three modalities: slideshow, two-dimensional (2-D) video and 360° VR video in an HMD. The proposed study will consist of three pilot experiments and one main experiment.
The proposed study has implications for both eyewitness memory researchers (i.e., the development of materials with higher ecological validity). In criminal cases, misinformation (e.g., leading questions, co-witness contamination) may lead to a false eyewitness testimony. Hence, examining how the differences between stimuli affect an eyewitness’ susceptibility to memory error is important. On a theoretical level, many studies rely on pallid materials in laboratory settings [7]. In comparison to two-dimensional videos and slideshows, VR could be a proxy for a real-life setting and serve as an additional modality to future research with ME paradigms. This study will serve as potential validation for the use of VR with the ME paradigm, and will introduce opportunities for further exploration in this field of research. Practical applications from this research could establish a new method of assessing ME using an ecologically valid scenario, such as recreating crime and accident scenes, or demonstrating an eyewitness’s ability to recognize perpetrators in a police line-up [1].
registration_responses.q4:
The following hypotheses apply to the main experiment for this study:

H1: Main effect of stimulus on memory errors: Slideshow > 2-D video > 360-degree video..  

H2: Main effect of post-event information, where memory errors due to misinformation will be greater than no information.

H3: Interaction between stimulus and post-event information; the difference between misinformation and no information will be largest in the slideshow condition, and smallest in the 360-degree video condition. If an overall difference is observed, additional t-tests will be conducted to further analyze the differences between stimuli based on a difference score of post-event information (misinformation, no misinformation)

We will supplement all NHST analyses with Bayesian analogues (i.e., Bayesian ANOVAs and t tests using “default” priors). We will also consider later exploratory analyses using more complicated models (i.e., multilevel models to examine item-level effects). Finally, we may also conduct exploratory analyses including the “Consistent information” statements (though these are not of primary interest for our main analyses)

Exploratory Analyses:

We may also conduct exploratory ROC curve analyses, plotting correct answers against errors (misinformation vs. other errors) across multiple levels of response bias (represented by different levels of confidence given with answers), in order to see whether the stimulus conditions differentially promote ability to discriminate between correct and incorrect answers. 

To examine the relationship between memory accuracy and presence in VR, we will correlate mean test scores with scores from the ITC-Sense of Presence Inventory (ITC-SOPI). 

We will also compare scores of ecological validity, engagement, negative effects and sense of physical space across formats, and tentatively predict a main effect of format, such that 
360-degree presence> 2-D video presence> slideshow presence. This analysis will serve as a quasi-manipulation check that the formats we used do indeed differ in the kind of experience they offer participants.

Regardless of whether the effect of format on memory errors/ME is significant, we may also conduct exploratory mediation analyses of Format -> X -> Memory errors/ME, where X will be each of the subscales of the ITC (Presence, Engagement, Ecological Validity, Negative Effects). These analyses will be exploratory for two reasons: First, though we broadly hypothesize that some aspect of VR might explain our predicted results, we have no predictions as to the specific mechanism. Second, mediation analyses typically require larger sample sizes, and it is unlikely that we will achieve adequate power for such analyses with our planned sample size.

Because the ITC-SOPI applies more directly to VR formats, we may conduct an additional mediation analysis identical to the above, but only in the 360-degree video condition. Again, we have no predictions as to the specific mechanism.
